item.description:
I’ve seen a few different people recently re-start personal blogs and it made me want to tinker with static site tools again… I’ve also been wondering how many little painting projects I’ve started and just left half-done here on Mastodon (11. The answer is currently 11).

So… still very much a WIP (another, add it to the count), but technically this works, syncing up Mastodon toots and stats as purely static content:
A little bit of a clean-up on the blade, and a first attempt at the dreaded eye lenses. At the most, absolute maximum, only 80% cross-eyed?

It has been weeks since I did any actual painting. I’m really not sure this effect on the pointy bit‚Äôs working, or even in keeping with the rest of the model, but it is ultimately more acrylic-on-plastic so I’m calling it a win!
Starting to add some secondary colours now that Tyrion-paralysis has ended.

I always intended to go back to this one and do a finishing pass or two before submitting to the competition on MMF, but the thought of doing so put me off any hobbying at all for several days üòÖ. So I‚Äôm calling this guy done. This will be the hero shot. Also the first mini photo I‚Äôve ever removed the ‚ÄòWIP‚Äô tag from.
Sketching in the light placement for Fancy Lad‚Äôs eventual Fancy Backside. Very rough sketch. (Please only squint while viewing üòÖ)
Fancy Trousers time.
And he‚Äôll need those mittens, it‚Äôs cold in space.

Head, shoulder, knee and toes (knee and toes). It may be a royal pain trying to colour-match freehand mistakes on a stippled shoulder gradient, but here we are. It‚Äôs all just a mix of the same two paints. How bad could it get üò¨

Random midweek experiments: I wondered if I’d be able to get a smooth blend from quite dark to quite bright going brown-to-ivories, without resorting to an airbrush. I think the answer is definitely ’no’, at least with this approach. It gives its own effect though, the scratchiness of it could probably be read as weathering? I’ll have to give stippling a try.
I appear to be locked into an Accidental Grimdark with this one.
Slowly stumbling towards something, I think. If you squint a bit.
NMM gold experimentation as the next random diversion I think. Definitely going to be handy to have a Truly Enormous version without any fussy small details to work things out on.
Let‚Äôs just take this panel by panel I suppose. Mess about with the Big Guy until something starts to look vaguely appropriate, then try to mimic it on his little friend.
What do we reckon here, HobbyPals? Is the freehanding actually accomplishing anything, or just distracting from the initial pleasant simplicity?
Another incredibly quick ‚Äòtwo-tone‚Äô test.
/taps temple: can‚Äôt be a bog standard ork checkerboard if it‚Äôs tilted into diamonds, that‚Äôs clearly elf territory‚Ä¶
It‚Äôs not the tidiest highlighting job in the world, but I‚Äôm slightly irritated that this very quick two-tone ‚Äòtester‚Äô model is already looking nicer than the stuff I spend weeks on‚Ä¶
Right, enough procrastination, operation Fix The Bad Shadow begins.

I added an attempt at a cast shadow on the base, trying to emphasise that I want the scene to read as though lit from a shaft of light above, but I hated it so much that I set it aside for a full week üòÖ I think it‚Äôs just far too extreme, I‚Äôll try to soften it and lighten it to recover.
His little boots have a strap around them that I wasn‚Äôt expecting. Sudden colour paralysis.

I have, definitely intentionally, decided that he should have Very Shiny arms. Didn‚Äôt come up much in the show, but a big part of the books.

(Awkward Look Monkey Puppet dot gif)
Starting into his jerkin and only realising while taking this photo that the filigree is approximately the same width as the ridges of my fingerprints üò¨
I mean I can‚Äôt leave him without hair‚Ä¶
Well‚Ä¶ I know what I‚Äôll be working on when I get the Farseer finished up. Can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs even smaller. Look at that likeness though, even just primed!
When I say ‚Äòfinish the Farseer‚Äô first, I obviously don‚Äôt mean not putting any paint on that tiny little face.
Blend, blend, blend‚Äîchecks to confirm that almost nothing has changed‚Äîblend, blend, blend. What even is white?

This stretch could be a long one: the Actual White bits.

Adding blue-gray over the vibrant white primer and a lesser white to the brightest white to try to make blue-gray and lesser white look like a more vibrant white (at scale). As you do.

Deep in the ugly, patchy phase of it at the moment.
Starting on gloves and bangles. Critical aspects of any wargaming mini.

Filling in the remaining white space on the torso. It‚Äôs only when you take the photo that you realise there‚Äôs a fair bit more imprecision than you saw with your Human Eyeball. Fair play to the YouTubers out there getting crispy lines while filming what they‚Äôre up to.
Expanding the red, waiting for the storm.

I can‚Äôt remember who originally shared the tip, but if you struggle (like me) to get your non-metallics to actually look ‚Äòshiny‚Äô, you can take a photo of your initial light placement on the mini and just boost the contrast to max and brightness to min. Try to match what you see with paint.
Slowly now pushing the painted contrast to better match the boosted version, trying to make the chest ornamentation seem like a distinct material from the fabric.
Never painted an elf before, space or otherwise, despite falling in love with Jes Goodwin‚Äôs art back in the day. But this little sculpt is gorgeous.
The order in which I choose to apply paint is both baffling and entirely self-inflicted.
Of course, gentle reader, he would start into some non-metallic nonsense before he even has the base colours down. The boy‚Äôs a fool.

I‚Äôm determined that 2025 is the year I actually finish painting a thing. Anything. Just one will do. I‚Äôm nominating this lil guy. Still a long way to go, but I‚Äôve stopped myself giving up in disgust and re-priming him three separate times now, so that‚Äôs progress!

Definitely time to start some regular creative stuff again and hope to carry hobby-momentum through into the new year.

Not the greatest start to day one though, I’m going to have to learn how to putty re-sculpt a resin-related-injury on the fuzzy fella.
Trying to mimic some of the light placement on the bracer referencing Sergio‚Äôs timelapse video. Still using quite a large brush at this point due to the Unaccustomed Vastness of space.
Even just roughly blocking in the base colours is going to take the rest of my natural life‚Ä¶
There’s something profane in tarnishing a pristine blank canvas.
And lo, the world‚Äôs slowest painter of yellows picks up again his burden.
Wait‚Ä¶ why exactly are we all using acrylics? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W3XRwj5l3Eo
Slowly increasing purpleation and general red enyellowment.
Hmm. Not sure if this reads as cast-shadow or just brush-slip‚Ä¶

Not only did the arm snap off, I hadn‚Äôt noticed that the face didn‚Äôt even print correctly until I reached it, so a quick segue into something else entirely. Let‚Äôs keep the purple theme and see if I can ultimately get this to read as metallic.
Kinda like these reds too.
From one meme to another, definitely not painting Skeletor for an attempt at this month’s Fedipaint.

Huh, turns out I‚Äôm genuinely not painting Skeletor. I remember him as purple with yellow accents, when he is, of course, blue with purple. Is it possible I just have a weird obsession with yellow boots now?

Well that‚Äôs less than ideal. Just starting on the non-metallics and he tried to run away. Now showing one of the real downsides of resin prints - on contact with soft carpet from maybe a one metre drop, ‚Äòhis arm‚Äôs off‚Äô. Half tempted to bodge an oversize Ork power claw on there.
The absurdity continues.
A braver painter would just straight up Bombadil this guy.

Eldest.

‚Ä¶ ?
It‚Äôs basically Orktober, right? The season arrives earlier and earlier‚Ä¶
Phenomenally niche, but üòç for those with the need. So many paint bottle holders! https://threadboards.com/index.php
I realise ‘unnecessary frilly bib’ may not immediately scream grimdark, but it definitely feels like a Blanche-ism…
Annoyingly, the thing I like most in this WIP shot is the texture palette üòÖ
Just the zenithal prime in place here before I intended to start a base coat of contrast red, but this looks so good I‚Äôm tempted to go for an old-school pre-‚Äòbone shaded‚Äô Deathwing experiment.
Slowly trying to add some colour and texture differentiation. I want to push towards a dirty, patinaed gold for the metal.
Currently trying to grok non-metallic metal. Baffled by how well it seems to be going.
